prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Claims for Breach of Confidential Business Information

para.paratext: In LAC Minerals Ltd. v. International Corona Resources Ltd.,[1] La Forest J. for the majority of the Supreme Court of Canada applied the test of a fiduciary relationship as set out in Frame v. Smith.[2] In the Frame case, it was established that three criteria must be met in order to establish a fiduciary relationship:
The fiduciary has scope for the exercise of some discretion or power.[3]
The fiduciary can unilaterally exercise that power or discretion so as to affect the beneficiary's legal or practical interests.
The beneficiary is peculiarly vulnerable to or at the mercy of the fiduciary holding the discretion or power.[4]
Fiduciary obligations can arise even where there is no confidentiality agreement.[5]

The existence of a fiduciary obligation is determined after consideration of all the circumstances. All three criteria need not be fulfilled in order for a fiduciary relationship to exist; however, the presence of all three do not necessarily lead automatically to the conclusion that a fiduciary relationship exists.[6] However, where the fiduciary has the ability to exercise some power over the owner or person in rightful possession of the confidential business information, it will be assumed that this power can detrimentally affect the beneficiary's interest.

LAC Minerals Ltd. v. International Corona Resources Ltd. (1986), 25 D.L.R. (4th) 504, 53 O.R. (2d) 737 (H.C.J.), affd 44 D.L.R. (4th) 592, 62 O.R. (2d) 1 (C.A.), affd 61 D.L.R. (4th) 14, [1989] 2 S.C.R. 574.
Frame v. Smith (1987), 42 D.L.R. (4th) 81 at p. 99, [1987] 2 S.C.R. 99; see also Anderson Preece & Associates Inc. v. Dominium Appraisal Group Inc. (2001), 309 A.R. 124, 2001 ABQB 1073 (Q.B.).
Atchison & Denman Court Reporting Services Inc. v. Neeson (1999), 1 C.P.R. (4th) 210 (Ont. S.C.J.).

See also Hodgkinson v. Simms (1994), 117 D.L.R. (4th) 161 at pp. 173–6, [1994] 3 S.C.R. 377; Norberg v. Wynrib (1992), 92 D.L.R. (4th) 449, [1992] 2 S.C.R. 226; Creditel of Canada Ltd. v. Boothe (1985), 7 C.P.C. (2d) 20, 6 C.P.R. (3d) 507 (Ont. H.C.J.); Talbot v. General Television Corporation Pty. Ltd., [1981] R.P.C. 1 (S.C. Vict.), at p. 8; Enterprise Excellence Corp. v. Royal Bank of Canada (2002), 20 C.P.R. (4th) 34 (Ont. S.C.J.).
See Gold Reserve Inc. v. Rusoro Mining Ltd. (2009), 54 B.L.R. (4th) 226 (Ont. S.C.J. (Comm. List)), leave to appeal refused 176 A.C.W.S. (3d) 832 (Ont. S.C.J.).

Hodgkinson v. Simms (1994), 117 D.L.R. (4th) 161 at p. 173, [1994] 3 S.C.R. 377. See also E. Weinrib, “The Fiduciary Obligation” (1975), 25 U.T.L.J. 7; C.H.S. Air Conditioning Ltd. v. Environmental Air Systems Inc., [1996] O.J. No. 1316 (Q.L.), per Adams J.
